FacilityName: G.S. Robins and Company (09 Home Office)

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Check valves and relief valves were inspected.
There is no equipment involved.  These are all chemicals just stored on-site.  They are stored in drums or totes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
G.S. ROBINS AND COMPANY

G.S. Robins and Company is a St. Louis-based, chemical distribution company with branch locations throughout the Midwest.  G.S. Robins has specialized in serving the unique chemical needs of the Midwest.  The company is involved with basic commodity distribution, transloading, custom blending, high quality distribution, custom packaging, and dry product particle size modification.  All blending, transloading, packaging and product particle size modification take place at this Home Office facility.   The branch locations are distribution warehouses.  The distribution warhouses move material, but do not work direclty with the chemicals.

G.S. Robins and Company is a long time member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD).  Through the NACD, G.S. Robins has committed and pledged to constantly improve the management and handling of chemicals by following the Responsible Distribution Process(RDP).  RDP is a system that promotes continuous improvement in the health, safety, and environmental performance of all member companies.  G.S. Robin's implementation of the RDP includes a commitment to comply with relevant environmental health and safety regulations.  The senior management at G.S. Robins has formally accepted these guiding principles.

RDP includes guiding principles for all aspects of environmental health and safety.  These include:  communication with emergency response officials, operating our facilities in a safe manner, respond to community concerns about chemicals, and to make health, safety and the environment a priority.  In order to verify that G.S. Robins has complied with the guidling principles of RDP, the NACD conducts a third party verification.  The on-site verification is conducted by a third party.  The third party audits G.S. Robins every three years.

The primary activities at the St. Louis facility consist of the following:  bulk chemical repackaging, drum and IBC storage, transloading, and custom b

Robins Emergency Action Plan consists of guidance for evacuation, fires, spills, tornadoes and bombthreats.  In addition, the plan contains information on emergency contacts, plant layouts, and emergency reporting requirements.  G.S. Robins conducts periodic evacuation drills for their on-site employees.  

G.S. Robins and Company is an active member of St. Louis City Local Emergency Planning Committee.  A representative of G.S. Robins attends all of the monthly meetings.  The LEPC meeting provide G.S. Robins with the opportunity to learn more about emergency response and to share the information about our facilities with the city.  Open communication with the city LEPC, fire departments, and other emergency response entities is an important component of our emergency response program.  Each year, G.S. Robins invites the St. Louis Fire Department to attend facility tours.  

CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY  
G.S. Robins and Company has learned important information about safety and the environment.  This has been learned both by participation in the RDP program and completing the RMP requirements.  Improvement is an on-going process.  The completion of the RMP program has lead to several process that are being re-evaluated.  Process hazard analysis' are being reviewed and updated.  Our emergency action plan is being reviewed and updated for all facilities.  And G.S. Robins is evaluating the inventories of chemicals stored and possible alternatives.

lending.  G.S. Robins has six of the 140 chemicals identified by the EPA above the threshold quantity.  These chemicals are:  sulfur dioxide, anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, formaldehyde, hydrofluoric acid and chlorine.

The worst-case scenario for G.S. Robins involves chlorine.  Chlorine is stored on-site in three different types of containers.  These container are:  2,000 lb. cylinder, 150 lb. cylinder and 100 lb. cylinder.  The worst-case scenario demostrates all of the chlorine on-site being released at one time.  The maximum amount on-site is 35,300 pounds.  The scenario would be either a fire or explosion causing all of the cylinders to release at one time.  The scenario has a Toxic Endpoint of 6.2 miles (offisite impact radius).   The modeling was done using the EPA COMP program.  The liklihood of this scenario taking place is remote.  

The alternative scenarios at G.S. Robins consist of problems that are more likely to happen.  As a chemical distributor, we move a large quantity of chemicals.  During the moving or storage of a chemical, there is always the chance that a container could begin leaking.  The leaking could be caused by several factors.  These factors include:  overfilling, mishandling, jostling during transportation or just a leak.  The following are the alternative scenarios at G.S. Robins.  These alternative scenarios were completed on the EPA COMP modeling program.

ALTERNATIVE SCENARIOS FOR OUTDOOR CHEMICAL STORAGE
The outdoor chemical storage consists of storage tanks and cylinders.  The on-site storage tanks are used to store bulk chemicals and fill drums and totes.  The cylinders are stored on site to ship to G.S. Robins outlying branches or directly to customers.  The Alternative Scenarios represent incidents that are more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario.  G.S. Robins moves a large amount of material through the facility each year.  The types of incidents that are likely to occur are:  drum leaks, tote leaks, and leaks in

tote valves.  
Release of chlorine from a 2,000 lb. cylinder / Leak in the cylinder / Toxic Endpoint = 0.3 miles
Release of chlorine from a 150 lb. cylinder / Leak in the cylinder / Toxic Endpoint = 0.1 miles
Release of sulfur dioxide from a 150 lb. cylinder / Leak in the cylinder / Toxic Endpoint = 0.1 miles
Release of sulfur dioxide from a 2,000 lb. cylinder / Leak in the cylinder / Toxic Endpoint = 0.2 miles
Release of anhydrous ammonia from 150 lb. cylinder / Leak in the cylinder / Toxic Endpoint = <0.1
Release of anhydrous ammonia from 42,000 lb. tank truck / Leak in connections, hose or truck / Toxic 
                      endpoint = 0.4
Release of 57,850 lbs. of aqua ammonia from storage tank / Leak in connections, hose or tank / Toxic
                      endpoint = 0.4

ALTERNATIVE SCENARIOS FOR INDOOR CHEMICAL STORAGE(all scenarios below are released in an 
enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air)
Release of aqua ammonia from 2200 lb. tote / Leak in the tote / Toxic Endpoint = <0.1
Release of total amount of aqua ammonia in the warehouse(drums & totes) / Fire or explosion / Toxic          
                      Endpoint = 0.2 miles
Release of formaldehyde(37%) from 2,500 lb. tote / Leak in the tote / Toxic Endpoint = 0.7 miles
Release of formaldehyde(37%) from 500 lb. drum / Leak in the drum / Toxic Endpoint = 0.3
Release of total amount of formaldehyde(37%) stored in the warehouse / Fire or explosion / Toxic 
                     Endpoint = 1.7 miles
Release of hydrofluoric acid (70%) from 157 lb. tote / Leak in the drum / Toxic Endpoint = 0.2 miles 
Release of hydrofluoric acid (70%) from 500 lb. drum / Leak in the drum / Toxic Endpoint = 0.2 miles
Release of total amount of hydrofluoric acid (705) stored in the warehouse / Fire or explosion / Toxic
                     Endpoint = 0.8 miles

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
G.S. Robins and Company has had no reportable accidental releases in the past five years.
